resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="If you have received a 404 error we apologize for the inconvenience.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="To better help us assist you, please provide the URL you were trying to reach in the support form." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Some web hosts don't allow you to upload files to your domain. To fix this issue you will either need to use another seperate host for these files or if needed we can offer hosting of the files and provide you with code that will show your video on your site. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Please make sure to provide the URL of your website and the name on your order." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="To customize your player, open up your website-spokesperson.js file in a text editor (like Notepad) or a code editor like Dreamweaver. Do not use Microsoft Word, Open Office, or other elaborate word processor software because they insert formatting code.It is important to understand that if you have more than one video, the file name in the line of code changes. For the second video replace website-spokesperson.js with website-spokesperson2.js. The third video is website-spokesperson3.js and so on.See the link below for more instructions on what and how to change each variable." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Create a folder called talkingheads. To function in must be created in the same directory that holds the page that you want to put the video on.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Now. Before uploading anything, please Unzip all the files from the zip file onto your computer. It is usually called download.zip
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Now Upload each of these files to the talkingheads directory that you created on your website host. Add the line of code below to your page inside the body tag:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="<script type="text/javascript" src="talkingheads/website-spokesperson.js"></script>" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Usually, when the video doesn't play, it is because the line of code calling the player isn't pointed to the exact file location. Check to make sure the files for your video are all in the same folder. Then make sure the line of code in your page is actually loading the website-spokesperson.js file by clicking on the link in your page code. If that works, now check the path variable in the website-spokesperson.js file to make sure the location path where the files are stored is correct. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="If you still have the problem, fill out the form on the left and make sure to include your website address." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Usually, when you get audio only for your video it is because you are hosting the video on a different domain. The files need to be hosted on the same domain as the page you have them on. If you can't store the files on the same domain you will need to use an iframe. This entails setting up the player on a page and then iframing that page. If you don't have the ability to do the iframe let us now and we will host it for you. Make sure to include your website so we can take a look." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="If you are having problems properly placing the player on your page there can be several causes. Often it is because the CMS/Web Builder you are using is forcing the position. Be sure to include your website address so we can take a look." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="If you see a box or white background around your video this means you are seeing the MP4 fallback. Usually means that the browser you are using doesn't support HTML5 canvas video. However there may be other reasons. Make sure to include your website so we can take a loo" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="This is usually because the browser you are using has blocked videos from auto-starting. if this is the case, we recommend using the MUTE auto-start variable so that the video is playing without audio but when they click on it the video will start over with audio.However, there may be other issues. So be sure to include your website address so we can take a look." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

terms.term: A 404 error is a common website error message that indicates a webpage cannot be found. It may be produced when a user clicks an outdated (or "broken") link or when a URL is typed incorrectly in a Web browser's address field.

Stands for "Content Management System." A CMS is a software tool that allows you to create, edit, and publish content. While early CMS software was used to manage documents and local computer files, most CMS systems are now designed exclusively to manage content on the Web.

A domain name is a unique name that identifies a website. For example, the domain name of the Tech Terms Computer Dictionary is "techterms.com." Each website has a domain name that serves as an address, which is used to access the website.

Stands for "Hypertext Markup Language." HTML is the language used to create webpages. "Hypertext" refers to the hyperlinks that an HTML page may contain. "Markup language" refers to the way tags are used to define the page layout and elements within the page.

JavaScript is a programming language commonly used in web development. JavaScript is a client-side scripting language, which means the source code is processed by the client's web browser rather than on the web server.
Stands for "Uniform Resource Locator." A URL is the address of a specific webpage or file on the Internet.

Web pages are what make up the World Wide Web. These documents are written in HTML (hypertext markup language) and are translated by your Web browser. Web pages can either be static or dynamic. Static pages show the same content each time they are viewed. Dynamic pages have content that can change each time they are accessed. These pages are typically written in scripting languages such as PHP, Perl, ASP, or JSP. The scripts in the pages run functions on the server that return things like the date and time, and database information. All the information is returned as HTML code, so when the page gets to your browser, all the browser has to do is translate the HTML.
Please note that a Web page is not the same thing as a Web site. A Web site is a collection of pages. A Web page is an individual HTML document. This is a good distinction to know, as most techies have little tolerance for people who mix up the two terms.
